segment.target: ms.ContentId: F0D47E70-0BA1-4A06-B2F3-0232C496709D

segment.source: title: Frequently asked questions
segment.target: title: Frequently asked questions

segment.source: Frequently Asked Questions
segment.target: Frequently Asked Questions

segment.source: 12-Nov update.
segment.target: 12-Nov update.

segment.source: Last updated: May 1, 2015
segment.target: Last updated: May 1, 2015

segment.source: What is a Windows Server Container?
segment.target: What is a Windows Server Container?

segment.source: Windows Server Containers are a lightweight operating system virtualization method used to separate applications or services from other services running on the same container host.
segment.target: Windows Server Containers are a lightweight operating system virtualization method used to separate applications or services from other services running on the same container host.

segment.source: To enable this, each container has its own view of the operating system, processes, file system, registry, and IP addresses.
segment.target: To enable this, each container has its own view of the operating system, processes, file system, registry, and IP addresses.

segment.source: What is the difference between Linux and Windows Server Containers?
segment.target: What is the difference between Linux and Windows Server Containers?

segment.source: Linux and Windows Server Containers are similar -- both implement similar technologies within their kernel and core operating system.
segment.target: Linux and Windows Server Containers are similar -- both implement similar technologies within their kernel and core operating system.

segment.source: The difference comes from the platform and workloads that run within the containers.
segment.target: The difference comes from the platform and workloads that run within the containers.

segment.source: When a customer is using Windows Server Containers, they can integrate with existing Windows technologies such as .NET, ASP.NET, PowerShell and more.
segment.target: When a customer is using Windows Server Containers, they can integrate with existing Windows technologies such as .NET, ASP.NET, PowerShell and more.

segment.source: What is a Hyper-V Container?
segment.target: What is a Hyper-V Container?

segment.source: You can think of a Hyper-V Container as a Windows Server Container running inside of a Hyper-V partition.
segment.target: You can think of a Hyper-V Container as a Windows Server Container running inside of a Hyper-V partition.

segment.source: Hyper-V Containers offer an additional deployment option between the highly efficient, high-density Windows Server Container and the highly isolated hardware-virtualized Hyper-V virtual machine.
segment.target: Hyper-V Containers offer an additional deployment option between the highly efficient, high-density Windows Server Container and the highly isolated hardware-virtualized Hyper-V virtual machine.

segment.source: For environments where applications from different trust boundaries on the same host, additional isolation may be required.
segment.target: For environments where applications from different trust boundaries on the same host, additional isolation may be required.

segment.source: Hyper-V Containers will provide higher isolation using an optimized virtualization and Windows Server operating system that separates containers from each other and from the host operating system.
segment.target: Hyper-V Containers will provide higher isolation using an optimized virtualization and Windows Server operating system that separates containers from each other and from the host operating system.

segment.source: Both container deployment options utilize the same management APIs, tools and image formats, at deployment time, customers can simply choose which deployment mode best meets their requirements.
segment.target: Both container deployment options utilize the same management APIs, tools and image formats, at deployment time, customers can simply choose which deployment mode best meets their requirements.

segment.source: When will Hyper-V Containers be available for use?
segment.target: When will Hyper-V Containers be available for use?

segment.source: We expect to deliver a preview of Hyper-V Containers this calendar year.
segment.target: We expect to deliver a preview of Hyper-V Containers this calendar year.

segment.source: Will Hyper-V Containers also be available to the Docker ecosystem?
segment.target: Will Hyper-V Containers also be available to the Docker ecosystem?

segment.source: Yes – Hyper-V Containers will provide the same level of integration and management with Docker as Windows Server Containers.
segment.target: Yes – Hyper-V Containers will provide the same level of integration and management with Docker as Windows Server Containers.

segment.source: The goal is to have an open, consistent, cross-platform experience.
segment.target: The goal is to have an open, consistent, cross-platform experience.

segment.source: The Docker platform will also greatly simplify and enhance the experience of working across our container options.
segment.target: The Docker platform will also greatly simplify and enhance the experience of working across our container options.

segment.source: An application developed using Windows Server Containers can be deployed as a Hyper-V Container without change.
segment.target: An application developed using Windows Server Containers can be deployed as a Hyper-V Container without change.

segment.source: Why do I have to pick between Docker and PowerShell for Windows Server Container management?
segment.target: Why do I have to pick between Docker and PowerShell for Windows Server Container management?

segment.source: This isn't desired behavior nor our long term plan.
segment.target: This isn't desired behavior nor our long term plan.

segment.source: PowerShell container management tools and Docker container management tools will work side by side in the future.
segment.target: PowerShell container management tools and Docker container management tools will work side by side in the future.

segment.source: With that said, using multiple management interfaces to manage the same container can be difficult.
segment.target: With that said, using multiple management interfaces to manage the same container can be difficult.

segment.source: Take, for example, creating a container with PowerShell and naming the image with an upper case character.
segment.target: Take, for example, creating a container with PowerShell and naming the image with an upper case character.

segment.source: Docker doesn’t support caps, PowerShell does.
segment.target: Docker doesn’t support caps, PowerShell does.

segment.source: While that specific example is very manageable, what gets much harder are handing state changes (race conditions and different expectations), feature set differences or versions…
segment.target: While that specific example is very manageable, what gets much harder are handing state changes (race conditions and different expectations), feature set differences or versions…

segment.source: Our short term decision was that management interfaces (in this case Docker and PowerShell) only see containers they created – you create a container with Docker and PowerShell doesn’t see it, you create it with PowerShell and Docker doesn’t see it.
segment.target: Our short term decision was that management interfaces (in this case Docker and PowerShell) only see containers they created – you create a container with Docker and PowerShell doesn’t see it, you create it with PowerShell and Docker doesn’t see it.

segment.source: As a developer, do I have to re-write my app for each type of container?
segment.target: As a developer, do I have to re-write my app for each type of container?

segment.source: No, Windows container images are common across both Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers.
segment.target: No, Windows container images are common across both Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers.

segment.source: The choice of container type is made when you start the container.
segment.target: The choice of container type is made when you start the container.

segment.source: From a developer standpoint, Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers are two flavors of the same thing.
segment.target: From a developer standpoint, Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers are two flavors of the same thing.

segment.source: They offer the same development, programming and management experience, are open and extensible and will include the same level of integration and support via Docker.
segment.target: They offer the same development, programming and management experience, are open and extensible and will include the same level of integration and support via Docker.

segment.source: A developer can create a container image using a Windows Server Container and deploy it as a Hyper-V Container or vice-versa without any changes other than specifying the appropriate runtime flag.
segment.target: A developer can create a container image using a Windows Server Container and deploy it as a Hyper-V Container or vice-versa without any changes other than specifying the appropriate runtime flag.

segment.source: Windows Server Containers will offer greater density and performance (e.g. lower spin up time, faster runtime performance compared to nested configurations) for when speed is key.
segment.target: Windows Server Containers will offer greater density and performance (e.g. lower spin up time, faster runtime performance compared to nested configurations) for when speed is key.

segment.source: Hyper-V Containers offer greater isolation, ensuring that code running in one container can't compromise or impact the host operating system or other containers running on the same host.
segment.target: Hyper-V Containers offer greater isolation, ensuring that code running in one container can't compromise or impact the host operating system or other containers running on the same host.

segment.source: This is useful for multitenant scenarios (with requirements for hosting untrusted code) including SaaS applications and compute hosting.
segment.target: This is useful for multitenant scenarios (with requirements for hosting untrusted code) including SaaS applications and compute hosting.

segment.source: Are Hyper-V/Windows Server Containers an add-on, or will they integrated within Windows Server?
segment.target: Are Hyper-V/Windows Server Containers an add-on, or will they integrated within Windows Server?

segment.source: The container capabilities will be integrated into Windows Server 2016.
segment.target: The container capabilities will be integrated into Windows Server 2016.

segment.source: Stay tuned for more information closer to the general availability.
segment.target: Stay tuned for more information closer to the general availability.

segment.source: What are the prerequisites for Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers?
segment.target: What are the prerequisites for Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers?

segment.source: Both Window Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers require Windows Server 2016.
segment.target: Both Window Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers require Windows Server 2016.

segment.source: These technologies will not work with previous versions of Windows.
segment.target: These technologies will not work with previous versions of Windows.

segment.source: Are Nano Server based containers supported?
segment.target: Are Nano Server based containers supported?

segment.source: For the TP3 release, no they are not.
segment.target: For the TP3 release, no they are not.

segment.source: Only Server Core based containers are currently supported.
segment.target: Only Server Core based containers are currently supported.

segment.source: Can I run Windows Server Containers on ESXi or another non Hyper-V hypervisor?
segment.target: Can I run Windows Server Containers on ESXi or another non Hyper-V hypervisor?

segment.source: Yes, Windows Server Container run on any TP3 Server Core installation.
segment.target: Yes, Windows Server Container run on any TP3 Server Core installation.

segment.source: Follow the instructions for enabling the containers feature in-place.
segment.target: Follow the instructions for enabling the containers feature in-place.

segment.source: Is Microsoft participating in the Open Container Initiative (OCI)?
segment.target: Is Microsoft participating in the Open Container Initiative (OCI)?

segment.source: To guarantee the packaging format remains universal, Docker recently organized the Open Container Initiative (OCI), aiming to ensure container packaging remains an open and foundation-led format with Microsoft as one of the founding members.
segment.target: To guarantee the packaging format remains universal, Docker recently organized the Open Container Initiative (OCI), aiming to ensure container packaging remains an open and foundation-led format with Microsoft as one of the founding members.

segment.source: Is Microsoft really partnering with Docker?
segment.target: Is Microsoft really partnering with Docker?

segment.source: Yes.
segment.target: Yes.

segment.source: Our partnership with Docker enables developers to create, manage and deploy both Windows Server and Linux containers using the same Docker tool set.
segment.target: Our partnership with Docker enables developers to create, manage and deploy both Windows Server and Linux containers using the same Docker tool set.

segment.source: Developers targeting Windows Server will no longer have to make a choice between using the vast range of Windows Server technologies and building containerized applications.
segment.target: Developers targeting Windows Server will no longer have to make a choice between using the vast range of Windows Server technologies and building containerized applications.

segment.source: Docker is two things, the open source group of projects and Docker the company.
segment.target: Docker is two things, the open source group of projects and Docker the company.

segment.source: We consider this partnership to include both.
segment.target: We consider this partnership to include both.

segment.source: Docker is successful, in part, because of the vibrant ecosystem that has built up around the Docker container technology.
segment.target: Docker is successful, in part, because of the vibrant ecosystem that has built up around the Docker container technology.

segment.source: Microsoft is contributing to the Docker Project, enabling support for Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers.
segment.target: Microsoft is contributing to the Docker Project, enabling support for Windows Server Containers and Hyper-V Containers.

segment.source: For more information, see the New Windows Server containers and Azure support for Docker blog post.
segment.target: For more information, see the New Windows Server containers and Azure support for Docker blog post.

segment.source: Back to Container Home
segment.target: Back to Container Home
